div.p: Placed in the entrance of Lincoln Park, El Parque de México is a sculpture garden that encompasses statues and busts of iconic revolutionary figures of Mexican and Mexican American culture. The reason for the creation of this park was to portray the Mexican presence of Lincoln Heights and the political ties between Mexico and the United States (Becerra). Statues of icons such as Emperor Cuauhtemoc, Dolores Huerta, and Emiliano Zapata can be seen with plaques that offer historically accounts of the persona as well as their contributions (Brown Pride). Ultimately in 1996, the Department of Cultural Affairs of the City of Los Angeles and Urban Art Inc. had agreed upon the preservation and restoration of El Parque de México (Urban Art Inc). In present day, sponsors use the park to hold festivities of cultural relevance that celebrate Mexican identity.

note.p: El Parque de México is a sculpture garden that encompasses iconic revolutionary figures of Mexican and Mexican American culture.
